articles.headline: Obama Acts to Aid Small Businesses
articles.snippet: The president unveiled a plan to reduce lending fees, ease the tax burden and increase bank liquidity to get credit rolling to small businesses.
articles.abstract: The president unveiled a plan to reduce lending fees, ease the tax burden and increase bank liquidity to get credit rolling to small businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said on Monday that it would try to ease a credit squeeze afflicting small businesses by buying up to $15 billion of securities that are linked to small-business loans.

articles.headline: Seattle Paper Shifts Entirely to the Web
articles.snippet: The Post- Intelligencer is the largest American paper to drop its print edition and become an Internet-only entity.
articles.abstract: The Post- Intelligencer is the largest American paper to drop its print edition and become an Internet-only entity.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE  The Seattle Post-Intelligencer will produce its last printed edition on Tuesday and become an Internet-only news source, the Hearst Corporation said on Monday, making it by far the largest American newspaper to take that leap.
articles.byline: By William Yardley and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: Nardelli, Defying Skeptics, Digs In to Save Chrysler
articles.snippet: Robert L. Nardelli said he fears consumers would shun Chrysler's cars, trucks and sport utility vehicles if the company sought court protection.
articles.abstract: Robert L. Nardelli said he fears consumers would shun Chrysler's cars, trucks and sport utility vehicles if the company sought court protection.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUBURN HILLS, Mich.  In his office at Chrysler’s world headquarters, Robert L. Nardelli, the chairman, works standing at an elevated desk. He thinks better on his feet, he said, even when he uses his computer.

articles.headline: In Downturn, China Sees Path to Growth
articles.snippet: A $600 billion package for infrastructure, training and research is aimed at making China more competitive.
articles.abstract: A $600 billion package for infrastructure, training and research is aimed at making China more competitive.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China  The global economic downturn, and efforts to reverse it, will probably make China an even stronger economic competitor than it was before the crisis.

articles.headline: State Colleges Also Face Cuts in Ambitions
articles.snippet: Budget problems have raised the question of whether universities have lost sight of their educational mission.
articles.abstract: Budget problems have raised the question of whether universities have lost sight of their educational mission.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — When Michael Crow became president of Arizona State University seven years ago, he promised to make it “The New American University,” with 100,000 students by 2020. It would break down the musty old boundaries between disciplines, encourage advanced research and entrepreneurship to drive the new economy, and draw in students from underserved sectors of the state.

articles.headline: Drones Are Weapons of Choice in Fighting Qaeda
articles.snippet: War has taken on a video-game quality, as missiles are fired on enemy targets from halfway around the world.
articles.abstract: War has taken on a video-game quality, as missiles are fired on enemy targets from halfway around the world.

articles.headline: Stimulus Money Puts Clean Coal Projects on a Faster Track
articles.snippet: The federal stimulus bill has allocated $3.4 billion for clean coal technologies, and companies are lining up with projects.
articles.abstract: The federal stimulus bill has allocated $3.4 billion for clean coal technologies, and companies are lining up with projects.
articles.lead_paragraph: EDWARDSPORT, Ind.  Near the middle of a dusty construction site here stands a patch of land, about the size of two football fields, notable because it is empty.

articles.headline: Obama in Effort to Undo Bonuses at A.I.G.
articles.snippet: President Obama ordered the Treasury Department to “pursue every single legal avenue to block these bonuses” and make the American taxpayers whole.
articles.abstract: President Obama ordered the Treasury Department to “pursue every single legal avenue to block these bonuses” and make the American taxpayers whole.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama and his top economic advisers scrambled to calm a nationwide furor on Monday over bonuses paid at the American International Group, even as administration officials acknowledged they had known about the issue for months.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: The Case for Paying Out Bonuses at A.I.G.
articles.snippet: The $165 million payout does sting, but the government may want to keep the employees right where they are.
articles.abstract: The $165 million payout does sting, but the government may want to keep the employees right where they are.
articles.lead_paragraph: Do we really have to foot the bill for those bonuses at the American International Group?

articles.headline: Goldman Offers Loans to Stretched Employees
articles.snippet: Working at Goldman Sachs has been seen as a sure path to riches, but its employees are losing money on their personal investments — particularly in Goldman’s own elite investment funds.
articles.abstract: Working at Goldman Sachs has been seen as a sure path to riches, but its employees are losing money on their personal investments — particularly in Goldman’s own elite investment funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs got its bailout. Now some of its bankers, those aristocrats of Wall Street, apparently need a bit of a bailout too.
